newsitem.title: INDIA: Indian banks seen becoming rivals to term lenders.
newsitem.headline: Indian banks seen becoming rivals to term lenders.

text.p: Indian commercial bank's entry into term-lending spells lean times ahead for financial institutions, already in a rate war, unless they radically alter fund-raising strategy, Prime Broking Company said on Monday.
So far only State Bank of India has entered the term lending market, but other banks are scouting for opportunities.

Other financial institutions' profitability will suffer in the coming years unless they diversify their income streams and access funds from retail markets to meet competition from banks, a study by the Bombay-based securities firm said.
Poor growth in credit and large lendable resources had induced some leading commercial banks to look at term-lending.
Banks had lower cost of funds, enabling them to undercut financial institutions in some recent instances, Prime said.

"Easy liquidity coupled with sluggish demand for term financing has resulted in a rate war in the market. If the rate war intensifies we could see the already thin spreads of financial institutions coming down to negligible levels."
Prime said financial institutions were slow responding to the challenge.
"None of them has yet set in place an organisation or system for deposit or retail fund mobilisation."

The first step for enabling market making in bonds issued by a financial institution have been initiated by the Industrial Development Bank of India (IDBI). It was too early to evaluate its success, Prime said.
India's leading institutions are the IDBI, the Industrial Credit and Investment Corp of India (ICICI) and the Industrial Finance Corp of India (IFCI).
"As far as improving investor communication and transparency of accounts are concerned, the financial institutions have a long way to go," Prime analyst Amit Rajpal said in the study.

Excess liquidity caused by repeated cuts in banks' cash reserve requirements and sluggish demand for bank credit has had a negative influence on financial institutions in the short and medium term, the Prime study said.
The financial institutions had raised over 20 billion rupees through public debt issues in the first half of 1996/97 (April-March) at costs ranging between 17.0-18.0 percent.
Only part of these funds could be disbursed in the first half, the rest having been deployed in short-term instruments.
"With the recent fall in the rates of short term instruments, the 'holding cost' of the money has shot up, impacting short-term profitability negatively," Prime said.
Borrowers were demanding lower rates for long-term money, affecting fresh loan sanctions and medium-term profits.

Indian financial institutions reported a sharp 31 percent fall in loan sanctions in the first half of 1996/97 mainly on account of recessionary conditions in various commodity markets and high lending rates.
"We see this slowdown in sanctions affecting disbursements moderately in the second half of FY1997 (April-March) and dramatically in the first half of FY1998," Prime said.
It said financial institutions were suffering a knock-on effect from India's policy of liberalisation, which has hurt some some sectors of the economy and reduced their ability to borrow.
